intro: Salacia pueblana, commonly known as the Pueblo salacia, is a species of flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the family Salicaceae, which includes willows and poplars, and is characterized by its small, yellowish-green flowers. The plant typically grows in arid or semi-arid environments, often in rocky soils, and is adapted to withstand drought conditions. Its leaves are simple, alternate, and have a slightly serrated edge, while its bark is smooth and pale in color. Salacia pueblana plays a minor role in local ecosystems, providing habitat and food for various insects and small animals.
